generated_encounter_updates.reason_display_text: Bilateral corneal neovascularization post-chemical exposure
generated_encounter_updates.transcript:
Doctor: Good morning Justin, please come in. You mentioned on the phone some ongoing issues with your eyes after that chemical splash a couple of weeks ago?
Justin: Yes, Doctor. My eyes are still really red, and it feels like there's sand in them all the time. My vision is a bit blurry too, especially in bright light.
Doctor: I'm sorry to hear that's still bothering you, Justin. Let's take a look. (Performs eye exam with slit lamp and fluorescein stain). Yes, I can see there's still quite a bit of inflammation and some scarring on the surface of both corneas. What's concerning is that I'm seeing some new blood vessels starting to grow into the clear part of your eye, the cornea. That's what we call neovascularization, and it's a response to the injury, but we need to manage it to prevent further vision problems.
Justin: New blood vessels? Is that bad?
Doctor: It's something we need to treat, Justin. It can cause more clouding if it progresses. I'm going to prescribe some steroid eye drops to help reduce the inflammation and hopefully stop these vessels from growing further. We'll also continue with plenty of lubricating drops. I'll also want you to see an ophthalmologist for a more specialized assessment. 
Justin: Okay, Doctor. Steroid drops and an eye specialist. Got it.
generated_encounter_updates.soap_note:
S: Justin, a 21 y/o male, presents with c/o bilateral eye redness, foreign body sensation, and blurred vision for 1 week. Reports accidental chemical splash to eyes (alkaline cleaning solution) 2 weeks prior, received immediate irrigation and initial ER evaluation. Symptoms have persisted despite artificial tears.
O: VA OD 20/40, OS 20/50. Pupils ERLA. EOM intact. Slit Lamp Exam: Bilateral conjunctival injection (3+). Corneas show diffuse superficial punctate keratitis, mild stromal haze, and early peripheral corneal neovascularization extending 1-2mm into cornea bilaterally. Fluorescein staining positive for superficial epithelial defects. Anterior chamber quiet. IOP: OD 16, OS 17.
A: 1. Bilateral corneal neovascularization secondary to chemical keratitis (alkali burn). 2. Persistent superficial keratitis. 
P: 1. Prednisolone acetate 1% ophthalmic suspension, 1 gtt QID OU. 2. Preservative-free artificial tears Q1-2H OU. 3. Schedule urgent referral to Ophthalmology for further evaluation and management, possible amniotic membrane or further intervention. 4. Strict eye protection. 5. RTC in 1 week or sooner if symptoms worsen.
generated_encounter_updates.observations: Significant corneal haze and active neovascularization observed in both eyes, right more than left. Patient reports significant photophobia and discomfort. Denies purulent discharge currently.

treatments.duration: 7 days then taper instruction by ophthalmology
treatments.instructions: Instill one drop into each eye four times a day. Shake well before use.
Use frequently to lubricate eyes and alleviate dryness/grittiness.
Urgent referral for specialized management of corneal neovascularization and chemical keratitis.

generated_conditions.note: Secondary to chemical keratitis from cleaning solution splash 2 weeks prior.
While neovascularization is present, underlying epithelial defects consistent with healing ulcers/keratitis.

generated_encounter_updates.reason_display_text: Follow-up: Chronic Kidney Disease Stage 3 due to bilateral renal hypoplasia
generated_encounter_updates.transcript:
Doctor: Hello Justin, good to see you again. We're here for your regular kidney check-up. How have you been feeling?
Justin: Mostly alright, Doctor. Still get a bit tired sometimes, but managing. Been watching my salt like you said.
Doctor: That's good to hear, Justin. Your blood pressure today is 145/90, a little on the higher side for our goal. How have your home readings been?
Justin: They've been around that, sometimes a bit lower. I'm taking the lisinopril every day.
Doctor: Okay. We checked your kidney function labs. Your creatinine is 1.8 and your eGFR is 45. That's stable compared to last time, which is good news given your renal hypoplasia. It means your kidney disease stage 3 is not progressing rapidly at the moment.
Justin: Stable is good. What about the blood pressure?
Doctor: We might need to make a small adjustment to your medication or re-emphasize the dietary sodium reduction. Let's talk about your diet a bit more...
generated_encounter_updates.soap_note:

States adherence to lisinopril 20mg daily. Reports home BP readings around 135-145/85-90 mmHg. Trying to follow low sodium diet.
O: BP 145/90 mmHg, HR 70 bpm. Weight stable. No peripheral edema. Lungs clear. Heart RRR, no S3/S4.
Labs: Serum Creatinine 1.8 mg/dL, eGFR 45 mL/min/1.73m2 (stable from previous 3 months ago). Urinalysis: 1+ protein.

generated_encounter_updates.reason_display_text: Routine follow-up for hypertension management.
generated_encounter_updates.transcript:
Doctor: Hello Justin, welcome back. How have you been managing your blood pressure since our last visit?
Justin: Pretty well, Doctor. I've been taking the Hydrochlorothiazide 25mg every day as you prescribed. My home readings have mostly been around 135 over 85.
Doctor: That's good to hear you're consistent with the medication, Justin. Any side effects like dizziness or unusual tiredness?
Justin: No, not really. Maybe a little tired some days, but I'm 62, so I expect some of that!
Doctor: (Chuckles) Fair enough. Your pressure in the office today is 140/88, which is a touch higher than we'd ideally like, but your home readings are encouraging. Are you still watching your salt intake and trying to get some walking in?
Justin: Trying my best with the salt, it's hard sometimes. Walking a few times a week.
Doctor: Keep up the good work with that, it all helps. Since your home readings are good and you're feeling well on the current dose, we'll continue the HCTZ 25mg for now. Let's recheck in about 6 months, unless anything changes, Justin.

generated_encounter_updates.reason_display_text: Post-CABG patient with recurrent, unstable angina and documented coronary artery spasm.
generated_encounter_updates.transcript:
Doctor: Justin, I'm glad we could get you in quickly. Your cardiologist called me, very concerned about this worsening chest pain.
Justin: It's been bad, Doctor. The pressure is stronger, and it's happening even when I'm just sitting and watching TV now. The nitro spray helps, but not as much as it used to.
Doctor: And you had bypass surgery back in '85, correct? 
Justin: Yes, that's right.
Doctor: Okay. Your EKG today shows some changes that, while not a major heart attack right now, are concerning for ischemia, meaning parts of your heart aren't getting enough blood. Given your history and these new symptoms, this is highly suggestive of problems with your bypass grafts or new blockages in your other arteries. The documented spasm component also needs attention. We need to admit you to the hospital for an urgent cardiac catheterization to see exactly what's going on with those grafts and arteries.
Justin: Hospital again... I was hoping to avoid that.
Doctor: I understand, Justin, but this is serious, and we need to act promptly to prevent a larger heart attack. We'll get you comfortable and start some medications to help stabilize things while we prepare for the cath.
generated_encounter_updates.soap_note:
S: Justin, 70 y/o male with h/o CAD s/p CABG (1985) and documented coronary artery spasm, presents with 1-week history of worsening angina. Describes it as retrosternal pressure, 7-8/10, now occurring with minimal exertion and at rest, lasting 10-15 minutes. Nitroglycerin provides only partial and temporary relief. Associated dyspnea. Denies syncope, palpitations.
O: Vitals: BP 160/95 mmHg, HR 90 bpm, RR 20/min, O2 Sat 95% on RA. General: Anxious, mild diaphoresis. CV: RRR, distant heart sounds, no new murmurs. Lungs: Clear. Ext: No edema. ECG: Old inferior Q-waves, new subtle ST depressions in V4-V6.
A: 1. Unstable Angina Pectoris (I20.0) in patient with known CAD s/p CABG, highly suspicious for graft stenosis/occlusion or severe native vessel disease (I25.710 - Atherosclerosis of autologous vein coronary artery bypass graft(s) with unstable angina pectoris). 2. Documented coronary artery spasm component. 3. Hypertension.
P: 1. Admit to CCU. 2. Initiate IV heparin drip, IV nitroglycerin infusion. 3. Dual antiplatelet therapy (Aspirin + Clopidogrel). 4. Beta-blocker (Metoprolol). High-intensity statin (Atorvastatin). 5. Urgent cardiac catheterization planned. 6. Continuous cardiac monitoring. 7. Serial Troponins.
generated_encounter_updates.observations: Patient is visibly anxious and diaphoretic. ECG shows ST depressions in anterolateral leads not present on previous tracings. Previous catheterization report from 1988 noted moderate native vessel disease and patent grafts with some noted spasm.

treatments.instructions: Chewable aspirin STAT, then daily.
For dual antiplatelet therapy.
Per hospital protocol for ACS/unstable angina.
Titrate for chest pain relief and BP control.
Urgent, to assess graft patency and native vessel disease.

generated_encounter_updates.reason_display_text: Follow-up for Type 1 Diabetes Mellitus and associated periodontal disease.
generated_encounter_updates.transcript:
Doctor: Justin, good to see you. It's been a few months. How are you managing with your diabetes and your gums?
Justin: Well, Doctor, the sugars have been a bit up and down, especially in the mornings. The gums are still a bit tender when I brush, but the hygienist said they looked a little better at my last cleaning.
Doctor: Okay, let's look at your sugar log. And I see your A1c today is 7.8%. That's a bit higher than our target of under 7%. What do you think is contributing to the morning highs, Justin?
Justin: I'm not always sure. Maybe my evening snack or the Lantus dose isn't quite right.
Doctor: We can certainly look at adjusting your basal insulin. And it's good you're seeing the hygienist regularly for your periodontal disease; that's very important with diabetes. Are you still using the medicated mouthwash?
Justin: Most days, yes. I sometimes forget.
Doctor: Consistency is key, Justin. We'll make a small adjustment to your Lantus today, and I really want to encourage you with the mouthwash and meticulous brushing and flossing. Let's aim to get that A1c down a bit by our next visit.

generated_encounter_updates.reason_display_text: Evaluation of chronic bilateral knee pain in elderly patient.
generated_encounter_updates.transcript:
Doctor: Good morning Justin. You're here today for your knee pain, is that correct?
Justin: Yes, Doctor. Both my knees, but the right one has been particularly bad lately. It aches constantly, and it's really stiff in the morning.
Doctor: How long would you say the stiffness lasts in the morning, Justin?
Justin: Oh, a good half hour, sometimes longer. It makes it hard to get going.
Doctor: And does the pain get worse with activity, like walking or climbing stairs?
Justin: It definitely does. Walking too far is a real chore now. I've been using my cane more often.
Doctor: I understand. We did get some X-rays of your knees. They show significant osteoarthritic changes – what we call 'wear and tear' arthritis – in both knees, more so on the right. This is very common at your age, Justin.
Justin: So it's arthritis then. What can we do about it?
Doctor: There are several things. We can talk about pain relief medications, like acetaminophen or anti-inflammatories if your kidneys can tolerate them. Physical therapy can also be very helpful to strengthen the muscles around your knees. In some cases, injections into the knee can provide relief. And for severe cases, knee replacement is an option, though that's a bigger discussion.
generated_encounter_updates.soap_note:
S: Justin, a 103 y/o male (DOB 1921-08-22, encounter 2025-05-29), presents with chronic bilateral knee pain, R > L, worsening over past few months. Describes pain as constant ache, 6/10 intensity, exacerbated by weight-bearing and activity. Reports morning stiffness lasting >30 minutes. Uses cane for ambulation. History of hypertension and CKD stage 3.
O: Vitals stable. General: Elderly male, alert, moves cautiously. Musculoskeletal: Bilateral knee crepitus and tenderness to palpation, particularly over medial joint line R knee. Mild varus deformity R knee. Reduced active and passive ROM R knee due to pain. No significant effusion. X-rays (recent): Show tricompartmental osteoarthritis, severe on right (Kellgren-Lawrence grade 4), moderate on left (KL grade 3).
A: 1. Severe Osteoarthritis, bilateral knees, predominantly right knee (M17.10). 2. Chronic pain impacting mobility and ADLs.
P: 1. Discussed conservative management options. Start Acetaminophen 650mg PO TID PRN for pain. Avoid NSAIDs due to CKD. 2. Refer to Physical Therapy for knee strengthening, ROM exercises, and gait training. 3. Consider intra-articular corticosteroid injection for right knee if PT and acetaminophen are insufficient. 4. Discussed pros/cons of knee arthroplasty in context of age and comorbidities, deferred for now. 5. Continue current management for HTN and CKD.
generated_encounter_updates.observations: Patient uses a single-point cane. Significant crepitus on passive ROM of both knees. Tenderness noted along medial and lateral joint lines, R>L. No acute signs of inflammation like marked warmth or erythema.

generated_encounter_updates.reason_display_text: Patient with known history of bladder cancer, now with hematuria and pelvic pain.
generated_encounter_updates.transcript:
Doctor: Rebecca, I'm sorry to hear you're having more trouble. The nurse tells me you've seen blood in your urine and are having some pain.
Rebecca: Yes, Doctor. For the past week, it's been quite noticeable, and there's this constant ache in my lower back and pelvis. It's different from before.
Doctor: When you say 'before', you're referring to your previous bladder cancer diagnosis, correct?
Rebecca: Yes, the one they treated a couple of years ago. I thought I was all clear.
Doctor: I understand. New symptoms like this, especially blood in the urine and pain, do raise concerns for a recurrence or a new issue related to your bladder. We need to investigate this thoroughly. I'm going to order a CT scan of your abdomen and pelvis, and a cystoscopy, which is where we use a small camera to look inside your bladder. We'll also get some urine tests to check for infection and cancer cells.
Rebecca: Oh dear. More tests.
Doctor: It's the best way for us to see what's happening, Rebecca. We need to get clear answers so we can plan the right course of action.

generated_encounter_updates.reason_display_text: Follow-up for known malignant neoplasm of right lower limb with suspected bone metastases.
generated_encounter_updates.transcript:
Doctor: Rebecca, thank you for coming in. We need to discuss the follow-up from your leg X-ray and the bone scan we ordered because of the persistent pain in your right thigh.
Rebecca: Yes, Doctor. It hasn't been getting any better.
Doctor: I'm afraid the bone scan shows increased uptake in your right femur, which is highly suspicious for metastatic disease, meaning the cancer from your bladder may have spread to the bone there. This would explain the pain you've been having.
Rebecca: Oh no... I was hoping it was just arthritis.
Doctor: I know this is difficult news, Rebecca. We need to confirm this with a biopsy of the area in your femur, and we'll also need to do staging scans, like a CT of your chest, abdomen, and pelvis, to see if there's spread elsewhere. Our oncology team will be closely involved in planning the next steps, which will likely include radiation to the leg for pain control and systemic therapy.
Rebecca: So, more treatment then.
Doctor: Yes. Our goal will be to control the cancer, manage your pain, and maintain your quality of life. We have a good team here to support you, Rebecca.

generated_encounter_updates.transcript:

Doctor: That's excellent news. Any side effects from the mesalamine?
Rebecca: None that I've noticed. I'm feeling more energetic too.

generated_encounter_updates.reason_display_text: Patient complains of progressive weakness, paresthesias, and gait disturbance; query Chronic Inflammatory Demyelinating Polyneuropathy (CIDP).
generated_encounter_updates.transcript:
Doctor: Alexander, please come in. You mentioned when you scheduled this appointment that you're experiencing some increasing weakness and unusual sensations in your arms and legs?
Alexander: Yes, Doctor. It's been going on for months, but it's definitely getting worse. My hands feel clumsy, I drop things. And my legs... they just feel heavy, and I'm tripping more. Plus this constant tingling, like my feet are always asleep.
Doctor: I'm sorry to hear it's progressing, Alexander. Have you noticed it more on one side than the other, or is it fairly symmetrical?
Alexander: It's pretty much both sides, maybe a bit worse on my right. It's the clumsiness and the weakness that's really bothering me. I used to enjoy woodworking, but I can't grip the tools properly anymore.
Doctor: That must be very frustrating. We did some initial nerve tests last time that were abnormal. Given the progressive nature and the symmetry of your symptoms – the weakness and sensory changes – we need to consider conditions like Chronic Inflammatory Demyelinating Polyneuropathy, or CIDP. This is an autoimmune condition where your body attacks the myelin sheath around your nerves. I'd like to refer you to a neurologist for further specialized testing, which might include more detailed nerve conduction studies, an EMG, and possibly a lumbar puncture or even a nerve biopsy to confirm the diagnosis.
Alexander: CIDP? I've never heard of it. Is there treatment?
Doctor: Yes, Alexander, there are treatments for CIDP, such as corticosteroids, IVIG, or plasma exchange, which can be very effective in managing the condition and improving symptoms. The neurologist will be able to determine the best course of action once we have a definitive diagnosis.

Sensory: Decreased sensation to light touch, pinprick, and vibration in a stocking-glove distribution to mid-calves and mid-forearms. Proprioception impaired at toes and fingers. Reflexes: Absent ankle jerks and biceps, 1+ patellar and triceps. Coordination: Dysmetria on finger-nose-finger and heel-to-shin. Gait: Wide-based, steppage gait, unsteady. Romberg positive.
A: Progressive sensorimotor polyneuropathy. High suspicion for Chronic Inflammatory Demyelinating Polyneuropathy (CIDP) given subacute onset, progressive course, symmetrical involvement, and mixed motor/sensory findings. Previous diagnosis of subacute combined degeneration may need re-evaluation or could co-exist. Rule out other causes of chronic polyneuropathy.

Provide walker or quad cane for gait stability pending further evaluation. 6. Safety counseling regarding fall prevention.

A: 1. Intermittent palpitations and lightheadedness in a heart transplant recipient. Differential includes: atrial arrhythmias (AF, atrial flutter, SVT), ventricular arrhythmias (less likely if brief and no syncope), sick sinus syndrome, medication side effect, electrolyte imbalance. 2. Adjust antiarrhythmics or consider EP study based on Holter findings and specialist consultation.
